Goal

Confirm the site supports both FTE and 12–24 month contract work without increasing exhaustion, identity capture, or geographic lock-in.

Invariant: If a change does not clearly improve one of the checks below, it is out of scope.

Core Design Principle

The site is not a marketing surface or a personal brand. It is a low-noise trust surface and a work-intake interface.

It must:

  • reduce ambiguity for the reader
  • reduce accidental obligations for me
  • allow multiple engagement interpretations without forcing identity

Acceptance Checks (Non-Negotiable)

1. First-Impression Test (≈30 seconds)

Open the homepage and ask, without scrolling:

“Would I trust this person to quietly solve messy problems without supervision?”

Not optimizing for:

  • excitement
  • cleverness
  • personality
  • ambition signaling

Optimizing for:

  • calm competence
  • clarity
  • legibility
  • seriousness without drama

If the page feels noisy, performative, or hustle-coded → simplify.

2. Identity Capture Check (Hard Constraint)

Scan headlines, bio, and section titles.

Remove or soften anything that implies:

  • founder / visionary framing
  • fast-paced / high-growth language
  • “wearing many hats” energy
  • passion signaling
  • destiny or future-casting

Prefer language that implies:

  • systems
  • reliability
  • judgment
  • translation
  • stability

Rule of thumb: If it sounds exhausting to live up to, it does not belong.

3. Geography Neutrality Check

Ask explicitly:

“If someone in Luxembourg, Philly, or a fully remote team read this, would it still make sense?”

Avoid:

  • NYC-coded assumptions
  • US-centric shorthand
  • in-office or local signaling
  • cultural proximity cues

The site should feel placeless, not nomadic-branded.

4. Contract Compatibility Check

Without adding a “consulting” or “services” page, confirm the site quietly supports contracts.

Signals to include:

  • emphasis on outcomes and artifacts, not tenure
  • projects framed as deliverables, not hero narratives
  • language implying independence and self-direction

A reader should plausibly think:

“We could hire this person full-time… or contract them for a year.”

If the site forces a binary, it fails.

5. Energy Profile Check (Primary Gate)

Read the site as a description of your future daily life.

Red flags:

  • constant meetings implied
  • emotional labor implied
  • evangelizing, selling, or persuading implied
  • being “on” all the time

Required signal:

  • deep work
  • bounded scope
  • calm execution
  • low noise

Invariant: No more quietly exhausting work. The site must enforce this.

6. Exit Narrative Check

Imagine entering via this site and leaving after ~18 months.

Good narrative:

  • “They came in, stabilized X, left things better.”

Bad narrative:

  • “They were supposed to be the future of Y.”

If it implies destiny or permanence, it is too sticky.

7. One-Sentence Sanity Test

After reviewing the site, this sentence must be easy to form:

“I help by __ so that __.”

If this cannot be done calmly and plainly, the site is still fuzzy. (The sentence does not need to appear on the site.)

8. Stop Condition

Once:

  • all checks above pass, and
  • changes feel marginal rather than structural

Stop.

Do not optimize further “just in case.” That is anxiety masquerading as diligence.

Work-Intake Layer (New Scope Addition)

Purpose

Add a professional intake interface that:

  • supports FTE and contract interpretation
  • filters out high-noise or exhausting work
  • signals ownership and process maturity

This is a funnel design choice, not a shift to firm or consultancy identity.

“Work with me” Page (Phase-Structured)

The site will include a “Work with me” page that functions as an engagement interface.

It may include:

  1. Short framing paragraph (what kinds of work this is for)
  2. Simple engagement flow (problem → scope → execution)
  3. Fit / not-a-fit boundary (explicit but calm)
  4. Structured intake (minimal friction)

It must not include:

  • services menus
  • pricing
  • client logos
  • growth or scale language
  • aspirational positioning

Phasing

Phase 1 — Structural Scaffolding (Ship)

Goal: The site is structurally complete without third-party proof.

Includes:

  • “Work with me” page
  • engagement flow
  • fit / not-a-fit boundaries
  • structured intake
  • recommendation slot (empty by design)

Excludes:

  • recommendation copy
  • testimonial styling
  • additional proof blocks

Phase 1 is complete when the site functions fully without a recommendation.

Phase 2 — Trust Insertion (Deferred)

Trigger: Receipt of a single recommendation from prior consulting work.

Action:

  • Insert one short, outcome-focused recommendation into the pre-defined slot
  • No layout or copy changes elsewhere

Constraints:

  • one recommendation only
  • ownership and stabilization focused
  • no hype, no future promises

Once inserted, Phase 2 stops.

Scope Boundary (Explicit)

This scope allows:

  • portfolio expansion
  • artifact-driven proof
  • quiet professional signaling

This scope disallows:

  • identity inflation
  • accidental consultancy branding
  • sales optimization
  • future-casting or destiny narratives

If a change increases identity capture, emotional labor, or implied permanence, it is out of scope.

Key Concepts

Visual Case Frame — A project presentation unit where a single decisive visual + premise + outcome dominate the first screen, turning the project into an argument rather than an entry. Aligns with design research, BIG / Red Blob / industrial design references, and what “pop” is responding to. This framing supports Acceptance Check #4 (Contract Compatibility) by emphasizing deliverables and outcomes rather than hero narratives.

Pre-Ship Validation (Phase 1)

Before marking Phase 1 complete, validate the site passes all 8 Acceptance Checks:

  • Check #1 (First-Impression Test): Homepage answers “Would I trust this person to quietly solve messy problems without supervision?” within 30 seconds, without scrolling
  • Check #2 (Identity Capture): No founder/visionary/fast-paced language; emphasizes systems, reliability, judgment, translation, stability
  • Check #3 (Geography Neutrality): Site makes sense to readers in Luxembourg, Philly, or fully remote teams; placeless, not NYC-coded
  • Check #4 (Contract Compatibility): Projects framed as deliverables/outcomes, not hero narratives; supports both FTE and contract interpretation
  • Check #5 (Energy Profile): Signals deep work, bounded scope, calm execution, low noise; no implied constant meetings or emotional labor
  • Check #6 (Exit Narrative): Implies “came in, stabilized X, left things better” — not “supposed to be the future of Y”
  • Check #7 (One-Sentence Sanity Test): Easy to form “I help by __ so that __” calmly and plainly
  • Check #8 (Stop Condition): All checks pass and changes feel marginal, not structural

Note: If any check fails, iterate before shipping. Acceptance Checks are non-negotiable.

Context & Strategy (Reference)

Objective

Establish a clear structure for the portfolio website that functions as a low-noise trust surface and work-intake interface. Record friction and required upgrades. No redesign or implementation now. Capture what must happen later during the execution phase.

Current State (Diagnostic)

  • Jekyll-based static site.
  • Minimalist design, simple IA: Home → Skills → Portfolio → About → Contact.
  • Portfolio contains three non-anchor projects.
  • Homepage lacks domain framing.
  • Timeline is strong but long; no fast summary.
  • Live demos (e.g., Streamlit) can be unreliable.

What Works

  • Clean minimal layout.
  • Clear page separation and navigation.
  • Tiles provide visual entry points.
  • Timeline shows depth and arc.

Friction / Gaps

  • Anchor projects not visible: Replacement Trap, Signal Storm, Walkability Index, Bantr.
  • No domain language on homepage (climate, housing, building systems).
  • Tiles lack “what this demonstrates” clarity.
  • Mixed project quality gives equal weight to non-core work.
  • No fallback screenshots for brittle demos.
  • Unclear whether Jekyll can support the desired “pop” for your long-term direction.

Core Constraints (Non-Negotiables)

Note: These constraints align with and support the Acceptance Checks above. Where Acceptance Checks provide specific criteria, they take precedence.

  • Time-to-legibility: A reviewer should understand what you do and why you’re credible within ~30 seconds. (Maps to Acceptance Check #1)
  • Visual dominance: Each flagship project must present as a visual case frame — a decisive hero visual with clear premise and outcome visible immediately. The project should read as an argument, not a list item. (Supports Acceptance Check #4: deliverables-focused framing)
  • Visual-first storytelling: Diagrams, architecture visuals, and screenshots do the primary explanatory work; text supports, not leads. (Supports Acceptance Check #1: clarity and legibility)
  • Progressive disclosure: Clarity first, depth on demand. Fast scanning layer with optional paths to deeper technical detail. (Supports Acceptance Check #1: reduce ambiguity)
  • Reviewer-optimized front door: Optimized for fast legibility by all readers (FTE recruiters, contract leads, direct team contacts), with optional paths into signal-rich deeper content. (Supports Goal: support both FTE and contract work)

Minimum Viable Target

1. Portfolio grid

  • Replace all existing tiles with 4 flagship visual case frames.
  • Each case frame:
    • One decisive hero visual (diagram, UI, or system map)
    • One-line design premise (what problem this frames)
    • One-line outcome / proof (what changed, shipped, or works)
    • Visual occupies more space than text (non-negotiable)
    • Text supports the visual argument, never competes with it

2. Homepage

  • Clear positioning in one sentence (meets 30-second legibility requirement).
  • Visual routing to flagship work.
  • Reviewer-optimized front door: Fast scanning, strong hierarchy, clear project arcs.
  • Optional deeper paths: Links to repos, detailed case studies, or technical deep-dives for signal-rich exploration.

3. About page

  • Add fallback screenshots for projects with fragile infra.

Inspiration Pass Checklist

Purpose: Determine whether Jekyll can be stretched far enough or if a V2 rebuild is warranted.

Status: [x] Complete

Reference portfolios: See “Portfolio swipe list” section below.

1. Hero Section

  • Evaluate positioning clarity across reference sites
  • Assess visual treatment (typography, spacing, motion)
  • Document: What makes effective hero sections “pop”?

Notes:

  • Maggie Appleton: Clear one-line positioning (“makes visual essays about programming, design, and anthropology”) + current role. Typography-driven, minimal motion.
  • Lee Robinson: Personal, conversational tone. Simple text hierarchy. No heavy visuals needed.
  • Andrea Ukleja: Photo + brief intro. Simple, human-centered.
  • Red Blob Games: Direct value prop (“interactive visual explanations of math and algorithms”). Content-first.

Key insight: Effective hero sections use clear positioning statements and strong typography, not complex motion. Most successful examples are text-first with minimal animation. “Pop” comes from clarity and hierarchy, not platform capabilities.

2. Project Grid

  • Evaluate differentiation between anchor and secondary projects
  • Assess thumbnail patterns and visual hierarchy
  • Review micro-interaction patterns (hover states, transitions)
  • Document: How do grids communicate project importance?

Notes:

  • Red Blob Games: Simple list format with clear categorization (Learn/Play/Ponder). Visual hierarchy through typography and grouping, not size differences.
  • Maggie Appleton: Grid with images + titles. Clean, scannable. No complex hover effects.
  • Andrea Ukleja: Simple navigation to projects page. No grid visible on homepage.

Key insight: Most effective grids use visual hierarchy through size, typography, and grouping rather than complex interactions. Simple hover states (opacity, slight scale) are sufficient. Differentiation can be achieved through layout (larger tiles for anchor projects) and visual weight, not platform-specific features.

3. Case Studies

  • Evaluate how depth is shown without overwhelming
  • Assess progressive disclosure patterns
  • Review visual-first storytelling approaches
  • Document: How do case studies balance clarity and depth?

Notes:

  • Red Blob Games: Each article has clear structure: intro → interactive demo → explanation → implementation. Visual-first with diagrams that explain concepts. Depth through expandable sections.
  • Maggie Appleton: Essays with strong visual hierarchy. Images support text, not overwhelm. Clear section breaks.

Key insight: Effective case studies use visual-first layouts (diagrams, screenshots lead) with progressive disclosure (summary → details → technical deep-dive). This is achievable with Jekyll through good content structure and CSS, not requiring complex frameworks.

4. Information Architecture

  • Evaluate speed to core work (how fast can reviewers find projects?)
  • Review About-page summary examples
  • Assess navigation patterns and page structure
  • Document: What IA patterns optimize for reviewer time constraints?

Notes:

  • Maggie Appleton: Clear nav (Essays/Notes/Patterns). Homepage immediately shows work. About page has summary + full timeline.
  • Lee Robinson: Homepage IS the portfolio - projects visible immediately. Simple nav.
  • Red Blob Games: Categorized sections (Learn/Play/Ponder). Clear hierarchy.

Key insight: Fastest path to projects = homepage shows work immediately or clear “Projects” nav. About pages benefit from 3-4 line summary at top + full timeline below. Simple navigation (max 5-6 items) is most effective. All achievable with Jekyll.

5. Visual Signature

  • Evaluate how sites “pop” (color, layout, motion)
  • Assess visual consistency and brand expression
  • Review motion and animation patterns
  • Document: What creates memorable visual identity?

Notes:

  • Maggie Appleton: “Pop” from strong typography, consistent spacing, gentle motion (subtle transitions). Visual identity through consistent design language, not flashy effects.
  • Red Blob Games: Minimal design, content-first. “Pop” comes from quality of interactive demos, not site design.
  • Lee Robinson: Ultra-minimal. “Pop” from clarity and personality in writing.

Key insight: “Pop” comes from strong typography, consistent spacing, and subtle motion (CSS transitions), not complex animations. Visual identity is built through consistent design language (colors, type scale, spacing system), not platform-specific features. Jekyll + CSS can deliver this.

6. Platform Clues

  • Identify framework choices across reference sites
  • Assess custom vs template approaches
  • Evaluate static vs dynamic rendering patterns
  • Document: What platform capabilities enable desired patterns?

Notes:

  • Maggie Appleton: Static site (likely Jekyll or similar). Custom design, minimal JavaScript.
  • Red Blob Games: Static HTML with Vue.js for interactive demos. Base site is simple static.
  • Lee Robinson: Likely Next.js (mentioned in reference), but design is minimal - could easily be Jekyll.
  • Andrea Ukleja: Simple static site, likely template-based or basic HTML/CSS.

Key insight: Most reference sites are static sites (Jekyll, plain HTML, or Next.js static export). Interactive elements (demos, diagrams) use vanilla JS or lightweight frameworks (Vue, D3) embedded in static pages. No complex server-side rendering needed for portfolio sites. Jekyll can handle all observed patterns.

7. Pattern Extraction & Decision

  • 3 patterns to adopt:
    1. Clear positioning statement on homepage - One-line value prop visible immediately (Maggie Appleton, Red Blob Games)
    2. Visual-first project presentation - Architecture diagrams/screenshots lead, text supports (Red Blob Games approach)
    3. Progressive disclosure in case studies - Summary → details → technical deep-dive structure (Red Blob Games, Maggie Appleton)
  • 3 patterns to avoid:
    1. Heavy motion/animation - Subtle transitions sufficient; complex animations don’t add value for reviewer-optimized sites
    2. Complex navigation - Keep nav simple (5-6 items max); most effective sites have minimal navigation
    3. Over-designed interfaces - Content quality and clarity matter more than flashy design; minimal UI lets work shine
  • Platform decision:
    • Jekyll can deliver 80%+ of desired patterns → Proceed with Jekyll MVP
    • Jekyll limitations are significant → Log “Portfolio V2 Rebuild” as future project (Next.js/Astro recommended)

    Decision rationale:

    Jekyll can deliver 80%+ of desired patterns because:

    1. Visual “pop” comes from design choices, not platform: Strong typography, consistent spacing, subtle CSS transitions achieve the desired visual impact. Reference sites show minimal motion is sufficient.

    2. Static site architecture fits portfolio needs: All reference sites are static (or static exports). No complex server-side rendering required. Jekyll excels at static content with good structure.

    3. Interactive elements can be embedded: For interactive demos/diagrams, vanilla JS or lightweight frameworks (Vue, D3) can be embedded in Jekyll pages. Red Blob Games demonstrates this pattern effectively.

    4. Timeline constraints favor MVP approach: Need portfolio complete before Q2 2026 job search. Jekyll MVP is faster to execute than V2 rebuild, allowing focus on content quality (which matters more than platform).

    5. Jekyll limitations are acceptable: The 20% gap (complex animations, advanced interactivity) isn’t critical for reviewer-optimized portfolio. Reference sites show that clarity and content quality matter more than platform capabilities.

    Recommendation: Proceed with Jekyll MVP. Focus on:

    • Strong typography and spacing system
    • Visual-first project layouts (diagrams/screenshots lead)
    • Clear positioning statement on homepage
    • Simple, scannable navigation
    • Progressive disclosure in case studies

    If future needs require more complex interactivity, V2 rebuild can be considered later. For now, Jekyll MVP delivers the required functionality efficiently.

Completion criteria: All checklist items completed, decision documented, ready to proceed with platform choice.
